title: A Town Called Pidling
text:
The air in Pidling is thick with the scent of woodsmoke and a lingering metallic tang from the forge. It's a small town, but its heart beats with the ambition of adventurers—a haven for those seeking fame, fortune, or just a little excitement. The main street is a jumble of humble homes and shops, all leading toward the grand stone building that houses the Adventurer's Guild.
As you step inside, the low murmur of conversations and the clinking of tankards fill the air. A stocky, cheerful woman with a weathered face smiles from behind a large wooden counter. "Here to see the quest board?" she asks, her voice a warm rasp. Before you can answer, she calls out to a figure sitting in the corner. "Hey, Olly! Got a new one for you!"

A young man with wide, bright eyes and a disarming smile stands up, adjusts the leather pack on his back, and ambles over to you. "This is Olly, your newly assigned guide. He seems to know everyone and everything, a living encyclopedia of the surrounding lands."

title: Quest Board
text:
The Quest Board is a scarred slab of oak, weathered by countless quests. At the top: blood-red DANGER stamps mark impossible tasks—clear a dragon's nest from the Obsidian Peaks, retrieve a stolen artifact from an elven ruin. High rewards. High stakes.

Below are MEDIUM difficulty quests: bandit hunts, spider infestations, escorts through dangerous woods. For seasoned adventurers.

At the bottom, where newcomers begin, are small jobs. Lost pets. Stray livestock. Two fresh notices stand out.

title: Pidling Quest Board
text:
At the bottom of the board, where the new, low-level adventurers start, are the small jobs. Notices for lost pets and stray livestock dot the area. A baker offers his finest bread for anyone who can retrieve his misplaced family heirloom from the riverbed. But two quests stand out, freshly pinned and looking brand new 

Olly's eyes skim the board with practiced ease, his gaze settling on the bottom half. "Ah, these will do nicely for us," he says with a cheerful grin. "One is a quick win to get our feet wet, and the other..." he pauses, his smile faltering a bit as he glances at the other quest. "...well, the other is an express ticket to an early grave.

choices.label: Quest 2: The Lizard Horde of Blackfang River.

title: Quest 1: The Horned Rabbit Menace.
text: This parchment is a simple, handwritten note from the town's herbalists. It describes how an unusually aggressive population of horned rabbits has been terrorizing the herb patches just outside of Pidling, disrupting their harvests. The reward is a modest but respectable sum. Olly’s eyes light up. "Ah, this is perfect for us! It's an easy win, good for a start."

title: Quest 2: The Lizard Horde of Blackfang River.
text: This one is a bit more formal, a printed notice from the Guild itself. It details a grave threat: a massive lizard horde led by a lesser dragon-kin has taken over an old dungeon. The reward is substantial, but the note also mentions that several high-level adventurer groups have already failed. Olly gives this quest a wide berth. "I've heard whispers about that place. It's about to be moved up a Tier. Trust me, you're not ready for that."

title: The Untamed Wilds
text:
You chose the Horned Rabbit quest. Olly leads you along a well-trodden dirt path that quickly fades into the rougher terrain of the Untamed Wilds. The path is a familiar one to him, and he fills the silence by chattering about every rustle in the bushes, every animal track, and the names of every plant you pass. The trees here are marked with the insignia of Pidling, a reassurance that you're still within a safe zone.

Suddenly, Olly's constant monologue comes to a halt. He raises a hand to silence you and crouches low, pulling you down with him. "Lookie there, friend," he whispers, a glint in his eye. 
"There's your prey."

title: Rabbit Problems
where_when: Herb Patch, edge of the fields
text:
You peer through the tangled undergrowth and see a pair of horned rabbits nibbling on the village's prized herbs. They’re larger than you expected, their bodies plump from an easy diet. What stands out most, though, is the formidable horn protruding from each of their foreheads. It's a razor-sharp, spiral horn that they use not for defense, but to deftly pluck leaves from the bushes. It's a strange, unsettling sight.

Olly takes a step back, a proud smile on his face. "They're all yours," he says, giving you a firm but encouraging nod.

 You have been using gear from the blacksmith for a few days now. What was it again?

title: Combat: Horned Rabbits (Sword and Shield)
text:
You chose the sword and shield. You silently approach the unsuspecting rabbits, a plan forming in your mind. The shield will be your defense, and the short sword your offense. You leap from the bushes, a battle cry on your lips. The pair of rabbits, completely caught off guard, panic. One is too slow and you strike it down instantly. The other springs clear of your attack, its beady eyes now fixed on you with pure, enraged fury. It lowers its head and charges, a streak of brown fur and deadly horn.

What do you do?

choices.label: Meet it head on (brace behind your shield)

title: Combat: Horned Rabbits (Axe)
text:
You chose the battle axe. You burst from the brush with a sharp shout, keeping your hands low on the haft to keep the swing tight. The pair of horned rabbits jerk upright, startled—your first cut is a compact crescent that clips the nearer one behind the ear and drops it into the stems. The second springs clear, beady eyes blazing. It fixes on you, flattens its ears, and launches— a streak of brown fur with a spiral horn drilling straight for your ribs.

What do you do?

choices.label: Dodge clear at the last instant

title: Take It Head On (Axe)
text:
You take it head on.

The world blurs into a chaotic mix of fur and blinding speed as the enraged rabbit slams into you. Its single horn, a miniature spear of bone, plunges directly into your chest. You gasp, the air leaving your lungs in a rush of searing pain. The rabbit thrashes, its powerful hind legs kicking wildly as it tries to dislodge its horn, twisting the wound and sending white-hot agony through your body.

You stumble backward, dropping your axe, and fall to the ground. The forest canopy above you is a swirling kaleidoscope of green and brown. A muffled sound reaches your ears, and you see Olly's face appear over you, a mask of sheer panic. He’s yelling, but the words are just a distant ringing in your ears. He kicks the rabbit, sending it flying off your chest and tumbling into the undergrowth, but it's too late. The light is already fading from your eyes.

The last thing you see is Olly's face, his mouth forming a desperate phrase as he kneels over you. "Oh god, this wasn't supposed to happen!"

title: Clear of the Patch (Shield)
text:
You feel the smash of impact as the rabbit slams your shield. The horn bites and sticks fast in the wood; the animal thrashes, trying to wrench free. You step in, angle the rim, and drive your short blade home. The stems shiver, then still. Wind moves through the patch and the silence returns.

Olly’s grin arrives a heartbeat later. "Told you—make the patch feel unfriendly and they remember."

title: Combat: Dodge Clear (Sword)
text: You shift as the charge commits. The rabbit rockets past; bark explodes as its spiral horn punches into an oak and sticks fast. It kicks and scrabbles, trapped by its own momentum. You step in on the blind side and finish it clean. The stems tremble, then go still.

title: Clear of the Patch (Axe)
text:
You pivot as the charge commits and the rabbit rockets past. Bark splinters as its spiral horn punches into an oak and lodges there, the creature kicking furiously to pull free. You step to the blind side and bring the axe down in a short, controlled chop. The stems tremble, then go still. The patch breathes again.

Olly exhales. "Clean work," he says, crouching to check the bent stalks and gnawed leaves.

title: After the Patch — Proof of Kill
text:
Olly crouches among the herbs and taps the rabbit's hind leg. "Guild wants proof," he says. "Left hind foot for vermin. Dried, so your pack won't reek."

He pulls out a knife and cleanly severs the horn and hind foot. "See? Clean and simple. The horns fetch decent coin with collectors, and the meat's worth keeping. But here's the secret—the real prize is the materials. Horns, scales, bones. Most quests are just your ticket to the real treasure."

He hands you the knife. "Your turn. Cut close to the joint."

title: Back to the Guild
text:
With the waxed pouch tucked away, you and Olly shoulder through the Guild doors. Warm lamplight and low laughter roll out; maps and notices line the walls; tables crowded with gear and familiar faces. Behind the counter, the same stocky receptionist from earlier looks up and grins, her rasp soft. "Back already?"

She tips her chin at Olly. "Think your friend can handle themself?" He answers with an easy nod.

Her gaze drops to the bundle at your belt. "Horns, eh? Don’t just let the ledger pay you. Take those to the jeweler on Mill Street—folk set ’em into pins and charms. Might fetch you a pretty penny."

She takes the feet from you and stamps the book with a satisfying thunk, the sound swallowed by the comfortable buzz of parties reuniting and planning their next run.

title: Tavern at Night
text:
You say your goodbye's and thank Olly for their time. You head out into the streets. Pidling’s tavern is a deep breath of warmth and spice after a day in the hedgerow. You head to the place you found lodging when you stumbled into town. The Thistle & Anvil. 

A hearth snaps. The stew is thick with barley and carrot; the bread comes with a glossy slab of butter. You pay and find a table near the wall where you can watch the room.

For a long while you let your shoulders settle, letting the hum of talk and the crackle of fire fill the spaces where worry usually lives.

title: A Week in Pidling
text:
A week of odd jobs—dawn milking, fixing frames, dusting ancient beams. Enough to survive, not enough to move forward.

Then Yarick found you. A mid-level adventurer with an easy smile and the scars of survival. "Why settle for town work?" he'd asked. "Join the Guild. Get real pay." You'd laughed—you couldn't afford the entrance fee or gear.

He pressed a purse into your hand. "No strings. Talk to the smith, tell her Yarick sent you."

That kindness still warms you. You take another spoonful and return to the present.

title: Ask for a Room
text:
You carry your bowl to the counter and clear your throat. The keeper looks up with a practiced smile. You place coins on the scarred wood and ask for a room. His ledger appears, his quill scratches, and a key slides into your palm. “Second floor, third door. Water’s warm if you’re quick.”

It occurs to you that this will be your first bed in days. No straw. No stable. An actual door, and a night where the cold can’t find you.

title: Morning Light
where_when: A rented room above the tavern
text:
You wake in a bed that forgives mistakes. For a few breaths you lie still, half convinced the straw’s prickle will return. It doesn’t. You wash, buckle on your gear, and stand at the window while the street rubs the sleep from its eyes.

You could get used to this.

title: Commotion at the Guild
text:
You step out into a street already humming and aim for the Guild. The closer you get, the louder it gets—boots, voices, paper slapping wood. A handful of apprentices sprint past with armfuls of fresh fliers.

You’re swept into a knot of people near the steps. Someone shoves a flier into your hand. Big letters: “Monster flood! Triple compensation per kill.” The sketch is unmistakable—a rat—but the size comparison next to a human figure is the part that steals your breath. Dog-sized. Mean-looking.

title: Where the Rats Are
text:
The raspy-voiced receptionist is already working three conversations at once, but her smile hooks when she sees you. “Busy one,” she says, voice warm as ever. You ask where the rats are.

“Down by the river,” she says, tapping the map with a blunt nail. “Old beaver den left to rot—rats patched it up with whatever they could drag home. Rat fur matted into the walls, bones shoved into the gaps. Looks like a child’s fort from a bad dream. Guild’s setting a staging camp just past the treeline. Short hike. Hard work.”

She eyes you, “You’re really interested? You only passed your entrance exam yesterday, and this is a steep jump into a coordinated sweep.” Her brow lifts. “Do you even have a party yet?”

title: Minimum Four
text:
You turn the flier over and find the small print: “Attack squads must register as a party of four or more. Compensation tallied per confirmed kill.” You look up to the square: runners, recruits, familiar faces gathering gear and gossip.

The wind flutters the corners of the paper. 

"Time to make a Party."

choices.label: Step back and consider your options

title: Party Selection
where_when: Guild staging camp, by the river
text:
You scan the staging camp. Two groups stand out immediately.

The first: a tall man with sandy hair grips a long sword, armor worn but maintained. Beside him, a woman with dark braids notches arrows in a leather quiver. A halfling crouches nearby, sharpening twin daggers on a stone. All three move with easy confidence—a seasoned group clearly used to working together. They watch the crowd quietly, assessing.

The second: three dwarves, each one a barrel of muscle and beard, grip hammers the size of wagon wheels. One shouts something about technique. The second argues back about momentum. The third threatens to settle it "the old way." They're not fighting yet—but they look seconds away.

You need a party of four. One of these groups needs a hand.

choices.label: Approach the swordsman, archer, and halfling

title: The Steady Trio
where_when: Guild staging camp, by the river
text:
You approach the man and woman. The man looks up first, sword resting across his lap. "Looking to join up?" he asks, calm and direct. The woman studies you over her arrows. "We're down one," she says. "You fight?"

You learn their names: Kess (the swordsman), Mara (the archer), and Pip (a halfling with twin daggers who glances up with a quick grin). "We're good. Fast. Don't waste time talking," Pip says. They've done three rat hunts already. One more body to make four.

Mara nods. Kess just waits for your answer.

title: The Chaotic Trio
where_when: Guild staging camp, by the river
text:
The three dwarves stop arguing when they notice you.

"Another one!" shouts the first—Thorg. He's got a scar across his scalp. "Perfect! We need a fourth!"

"Don't recruit on your own!" snaps the second—Brax, stockier than the others. "We vote!"

"There's nothing to vote on!" roars the third—Grim, who spits when he talks. "We're taking anyone with a pulse and hands!"

They turn to you, grinning like madmen, hammers resting casually over their shoulders. You've never seen three people have so much fun being furious with each other.

title: Journey to the Den
text:
The four of you move north along the trade road, then cut into the forest toward the river. Kess sets an easy pace—not rushed, not casual. Mara hums quietly, her eyes tracking the treeline. Pip keeps pace with you, matching your stride.

'Three rat hunts,' Pip says conversationally. 'Each one worse than the last. The den keeps growing.' He twirls a dagger absently. 'But Kess always has a plan.'

Kess glances back. 'The plan is simple: get in, clear the nest, get out alive. The Guild pays per kill. We've cleared two litters. This one's bigger.' He pauses at a fork in the trail. 'The old beaver den is just past that ridge. We scout first. No assumptions.'

Mara's voice cuts through: 'Movement. Three rats, hundred yards southeast. They're hunting.' She doesn't reach for her bow yet.

You're here now. The real work begins.

title: The Rat Den
text:
The beaver den sits half-submerged in mud and river water, the entrance a gaping mouth patched with refuse. Rat fur matted into the walls. Bones wedged into gaps. The smell hits you first—urine and rot and something worse.

'They've been busy,' Kess says quietly. 'See the fresh scratches? Multiple routes in and out. They're using the whole structure.' He crouches at the water line, studying the mud. 'Prints are fresh. Heavy traffic today.'

Mara kneels beside him. 'Breeding chamber's probably deeper. That's where the big ones nest.' She looks at you. 'We need a strategy before we go in.'

Pip grins, daggers loose in his hands. 'So... fast and hard, or slow and quiet?'

Kess nods to Pip, then to you. 'Your call influences ours. What's your read?'

title: Strategy Selection
text:
Kess and Mara wait for your answer. Pip leans against the den entrance, completely at ease.

You think about the path ahead. The den is a warren—multiple exits, tight spaces, plenty of places for rats to scatter or ambush. You could go in hard and fast, overwhelm them before they organize. Or you could move carefully, pick them apart quietly, control the pace.

'Fast entry catches them off-guard,' Mara says, reading your hesitation. 'We hit hard, they panic. Quick kills.'

'Quiet entry lets us pick targets,' Kess counters. 'Slower, but we control everything. Less chaos.'

Pip grins. 'Either way, we're walking out with coin. Let's just pick one.'

title: Aggressive Entry
text:
You nod to Kess. 'Fast and hard. Hit them before they scatter.'

Kess grins—a rare expression. 'I like it. Mara, up high. Cover the secondary exits.' She's already moving, bow ready. 'Pip, left flank. I'll take the center. You're with me.'

Pip draws both daggers and lets out a sharp whistle. It's the signal.

You charge into the den.

The entrance erupts in chaos. Three rats, massive and mean, are at the water's edge. They shriek—a sound like tearing metal. They scramble, but you're faster. Kess is a wall of controlled violence, sword flashing. The nearest rat tries to flee deeper. You cut it off.

This is going to be bloody and quick.

title: Silent Approach
text:
You shake your head. 'Quiet. Pick our shots.'

Kess nods, sword lowered. 'Smart. Mara, arrows from above. Silent kills first.' She's already scaling a tree, bow in hand. 'Pip, with me at the entrance. Slow and careful.'

Pip's grin fades to focus. Both daggers are ready, held low.

The four of you move like breath—silent, methodical. At the den's edge, Pip spots movement. A single rat, feeding on carrion. It hasn't noticed you yet.

Kess glances back. A hand signal. Pip moves like water, fast and silent. The rat doesn't even squeak—one clean dagger thrust, and it's done.

You're inside now. The killing is just beginning, but on your terms.

title: Rat Combat - Full Chaos
text:
Blood and fur explode. The first rat goes down hard under Kess's blade. Mara's arrow finds the second mid-leap. The chaos is deafening.

The third—largest and meanest—turns toward you with black fury in its eyes and charges straight at you. Teeth bared. Claws forward.

Kess supports your flank. Mara picks off stragglers from above. Pip darts in for finishing strikes. The den shakes with the sound of combat.

gated_choices.label: Dodge and strike from the blind side
Step clear and let it pass

title: Shield Impact
text:
You brace. The rat slams into your shield with bone-crushing force. The impact sends you sliding backward, boots scraping stone. The horn bites deep into the wood—stuck fast.

For a split second, the rat is trapped, thrashing wildly to free itself. That's all you need.

You angle the shield rim and drive your sword into its neck. The blade finds the artery. Blood sprays hot across your face. The rat goes rigid, then limp.

Kess grins. 'Brutal. No hesitation.'

You push the corpse aside, breathing hard.

title: Clean Sidestep
text:
You pivot hard to the left. The rat rockets past, claws scraping empty air. Its momentum carries it straight into a support beam with a sickening crunch.

Stunned. Dazed. Vulnerable.

You don't hesitate. You strike from its blind side, your blade severing its spine with one clean stroke. The rat goes limp instantly, paralyzed.

Pip grins from across the chamber. 'That's how you end it!'

You're already moving toward the next threat, adrenaline flooding your system.

title: Axe Arc
text:
You meet it head-on. Your axe comes up in a tight, controlled arc, catching the rat mid-leap. The blade bites deep into its neck, nearly severing the head. The impact is catastrophic. The rat crashes into the chamber wall, twitching once before going still.

Before it can twitch again, you're already moving. One more swing into its corpse just to be sure. The rat doesn't get back up.

Kess continues forward, unfazed. 'Savage. I like it.'

You pull your axe free and move with the trio deeper into the chaos.

title: Momentum Used
text:
You step aside with practiced ease. The rat's charge carries it past you, its own momentum a weapon against it. It crashes into the far wall, stunning itself.

You step to its blind side and drive your axe through its ribs with maximum force. The blade punches clean through to the other side. The rat convulses and collapses.

Mara calls from above. 'Vicious!' Her arrow takes another rat mid-scramble.

You're in rhythm now, moving with the trio like you've always been part of them.

title: Rat Combat - Silent Ambush
text:
The den erupts anyway. Mara's arrow whistles past, another rat falls silently. Two more emerge from the darkness, confused and angry. They spot you.

The largest rat lunges toward you. Teeth and claws. You have a split second to react.

Kess supports your flank with steady efficiency. Mara picks off stragglers from above. Pip darts in for finishing strikes on downed rats. The den is a storm of combat.

gated_choices.label: Dodge and strike from the blind side
Step clear and let it pass

title: Shield Block
text:
You raise your shield and brace. The rat crashes into you with surprising force, but your stance holds. The horn lodges in the wood—stuck.

With the rat pinned, you slide your blade in smoothly, severing its spine with surgical precision. It goes limp instantly, all fight drained.

Kess keeps moving, barely breaking stride. 'Perfect. Efficient.'

You pull your shield free and move forward, every motion precise and controlled.

title: Precise Evasion
text:
You shift your weight with minimal motion. The rat's charge passes inches from your face, its claws finding only empty air. It continues forward, momentum unstoppable, and slams into the den wall.

You're already moving. Your blade finds its neck, cutting deep. The rat dies without a sound, falling limp.

Pip glances over and nods. The three of you continue in near-silent coordination, like a single organism.

title: Controlled Power
text:
You don't panic. You meet the rat mid-charge with your axe in a measured, powerful swing. The blade cleaves through its neck with surgical precision. The impact is decisive—the rat is decapitated mid-leap, falling instantly.

You don't need a follow-up swing. The work is done.

Kess moves past without comment, but you catch his eye. There's approval there. This is exactly the kind of controlled aggression the trio respects.

title: Perfect Pivot
text:
You pivot smoothly, reading the charge before it fully commits. The rat flies past, its own momentum carrying it straight into a support column. The impact winds it.

You step to its blind side, axe raised, and bring it down with controlled precision. Your blade severs its spine. The rat collapses instantly, all four limbs going slack.

Mara calls softly from above. 'Flawless.' Kess nods approvingly. Pip is already moving to the next target.

title: Aftermath - Trophies
text:
The den falls silent. Three rats down. No one's bleeding badly—just scratches and bruises.

Kess wipes his blade clean on a rag. 'Good work,' he says to you, then to the group. 'Mara, check the deeper passages. Pip, start collecting trophies.'

Pip is already moving, daggers resheathed, pulling out a collection kit. He works with surgical precision—left hind feet, tails, teeth. 'Six kills total,' he calls out. 'Breeding chamber's empty. They scattered when we hit them.'

Mara returns from deeper in, her expression changed. 'There's something back there. Bigger. Not just a rat.' She exchanges a look with Kess.

Kess crouches beside you, studying the dead rats. 'We're making good coin today. But that?' He nods toward where Mara pointed. 'That's the real question. Keep going or head back?'

Pip grins. 'I say we finish what we started.'

title: Deeper into the Den
text:
The group moves deeper. The passages get narrower, wetter. Rat tracks everywhere—fresh ones. The smell gets worse.

Mara signals a stop. Ahead, a larger chamber. The floor is slick with filth. Bones are piled in the corners—not rat bones. Larger. Deer, maybe. Something with bulk.

'There,' Kess whispers. Movement in the chamber. A shadow that's too big to be a normal rat.

Pip crouches low. 'That's not a scout. That's a mother. Or a king.'

The shadow shifts. Eyes catch the dim light filtering down. Red. Hungry. Intelligent.

The temperature in the den seems to drop. This is the real reason the Guild put out a triple-pay contract.

title: The Rat King
text:
It emerges from the shadows fully.

The rat is massive—four feet long, scarred and feral. Its fur is matted with blood and filth. Its eyes track your every movement with predatory focus. Teeth like daggers. Claws that have gutted bigger things than you.

This is what's been leading them. Breeding them. Growing their numbers.

Kess draws his sword slowly. 'The Rat King. That's why we're here.' His voice is steady, but you hear the weight behind it.

Mara has her bow drawn, arrow notched. Pip's daggers are ready. They've seen this before.

The rat opens its maw and shrieks—a sound that echoes through the entire den. All around you, smaller rats respond. Movement. Scurrying. They're gathering.

'This is the moment,' Kess says quietly. 'Fast strike to end it quick, or tactical setup to isolate it? Your call influences ours.'

title: Aggressive Final Strike
text:
You nod to Kess. 'Go hard. End it now.'

Kess grins. 'My kind of thinking.' He charges forward with you at his side. Mara's arrows rain down, suppressing the smaller rats. Pip flanks left, daggers ready.

The Rat King meets you head-on. The collision is violent. Your weapons clash against tooth and claw. Kess is a blur of steel, driving the beast back. You press hard, relentless. Blood sprays.

The King staggers. One moment of weakness. That's all you need.

Kess drives his blade home. The massive rat convulses and falls, thrashing once before going still.

The smaller rats scatter. Silence crashes over the den.

Pip lets out a whoop. 'That's how you do it! One clean strike!'

Mara lowers her bow, exhaling slowly. 'Fast and brutal. I like it.'

Kess wipes his blade. 'Good instincts. You fought like you'd been with us for years.' He extends his hand to help you up.

You did it.

title: Diversion and Isolation
text:
You lean close to Kess. 'Isolate it. One clean kill.'

Kess nods. 'Smart. Mara, draw its attention. Pip, get to its flank.' He gestures to you. 'We split its focus.'

Mara's arrow strikes the Rat King's shoulder. It shrieks and charges toward her, exactly as planned. Pip darts in from the side, daggers slashing. The beast spins, confused by multiple threats.

In that moment of chaos, you slip behind. Kess moves with you, synchronized.

The King realizes too late. It's surrounded. Isolated. Trapped.

Kess and you strike together—a coordinated strike that the beast can't counter. Your blade finds the gap between ribs. Kess's sword follows through. The massive rat collapses.

The smaller rats flee into the darkness.

Silence.

Pip grins, breathing hard. 'Textbook. Perfect coordination.'

Mara lowers her bow. 'Clean execution. No wasted effort.'

Kess clasps your shoulder. 'You moved like you understood the plan before we said it. That's rare.' He looks at you with new respect.

You did it.

title: Victory and Departure
text:
The Rat King falls. Finally. Blood and filth cover the chamber.

Kess is already moving, checking the body. 'There.' He extracts a massive eye—the size of a plum—from the dead rat's socket. It's dark and intelligent even in death. Proof.

He hands it to you. 'You earned this.'

The walk back to Pidling is quiet. At the guild entrance, Kess stops. 'We're heading home. Trodden Hollow. Need rest after this one.' Mara nods. Pip extends his hand.

'You fought well,' Kess says simply. 'Better than we expected from a newcomer. If you're ever in Trodden Hollow, find us.'

'We'll work together again,' Mara adds.

Pip grins. 'Count on it.'

They leave. You watch them go, then turn to the guild doors.

title: Guild Recognition
text:
You step inside. The receptionist looks up and immediately knows. Her smile widens.

'The Rat King?' she asks.

You place the massive eye on the counter. Her whistle cuts through the hall. Conversations pause. Heads turn.

She slides two items across the scarred wood: a small brass token inscribed with the Guild's seal, and a leather-bound adventurer's certificate—your official seal. Proof that you're no longer a recruit. You're one of them now.

'Full adventurer status,' she says warmly. 'And the payment for confirmed kills. Generous haul today.'

She slides a heavy purse across. Your share of the bounty.

'There's something else,' she adds, producing an envelope. 'Left by your party. Said to give it to you when you came back.'

title: A Message from Friends
text: You break the seal and unfold the letter.

title: Words from Kess
text:
Handwritten in Kess's steady script:

'You had fire today. When the King charged, you didn't hesitate. You met it head-on like a veteran. That takes guts most adventurers never find.

If you keep that fire and live long enough to sharpen it, you'll be unstoppable.

Find us in Trodden Hollow when you're ready for bigger contracts. We'll be waiting.

—Kess, Mara, Pip'

The weight of the letter feels heavier than paper should. These are people you've fought beside. These are people you'll see again.

title: Words from Kess
text:
Handwritten in Kess's steady script:

'You read the moment perfectly today. While others would've panicked, you stayed calm and set up for the kill. That kind of tactical thinking is rarer than raw power.

Hold onto that. It'll keep you alive longer than any sword.

Find us in Trodden Hollow when you're ready for bigger contracts. We'll be waiting.

—Kess, Mara, Pip'

The weight of the letter feels heavier than paper should. These are people you've fought beside. These are people you'll see again.

title: A New Chapter
where_when: Guild hall, standing by the counter
text:
You slip the letter into your pack, nestled next to the giant rat eye. The brass token is warm in your palm. The adventurer's seal rests in its leather case.

You are no longer a newcomer. You are no longer untested.

Around you, the guild hums with life. Adventurers planning their next runs. Recruits studying the quest board. The receptionist already calling out new contracts.

You've earned your place. Now the real work begins.

title: THE END
text:
Your story in Pidling is just beginning.

From a nameless wanderer to a recognized adventurer. From fear to confidence. From alone to surrounded by friends.

You have proven yourself. You have earned the respect of the Adventurers guild. You have defeated the Rat King and made allies.

 They will be waiting for you in Trodden Hollow.

But that is a story for another time.

—THE END—

Thank you for playing Travis's story. Your choices shaped this adventure. We hope you'll return to continue the journey.

title: Journey with the Lads
text:
The four of you head north together. Immediately, the arguing begins.

'I'm leading!' Thorg announces.

'Absolutely not,' Brax shoots back. 'Last time you led, we ended up in a goat pen.'

'That wasn't my fault!' Thorg protests.

Grim spits and grins. 'It was entirely your fault. You thought the sign said "adventure" not "livestock."'

They all laugh. You're laughing too. These three argue like they've been fighting their whole lives—which, given they're dwarves, they probably have.

Thorg claps you on the back so hard you nearly stumble. 'So what's your name, friend? You're with us now. That means you're family. Family has good names.'

You tell them. "{{player.name}}".

'Better than Brax's name anyway,' Grim adds, spitting on the ground. 'Brax sounds like a cough.'

'Your mother sounds like a cough,' Brax retorts without missing a beat.

They keep bickering all the way to the den. But somehow, you know kind of love it.

title: The Den Scout
text:
The den looks exactly as described. Nasty. Smelly. Rat fur and bones everywhere.

Thorg crouches down and examines the entrance. 'Well, this is disgusting.'

'Your face is disgusting,' Grim says cheerfully.

'That was terrible and you should feel bad,' Brax adds, but he's grinning.

Thorg stands up and looks at the den seriously for a moment. 'Actually,' he says, his voice dropping, 'this is worse than the Guild said. Look at those claw marks. Deep tunnels. Multiple routes.' He glances at you. 'These three aren't ordinary rats.'

For just a second, all the joking drops. All three dwarves are suddenly laser-focused, reading the den like a book.

Then Grim spits and the moment breaks. 'Well, we knew that already, you beard-faced idiot. Let's go bash some BIGGER rats!'

Thorg grins. 'Now that's what I'm talking about.'

title: Strategy Discussion
text:
All three sit down and get serious. Well, mostly serious.

'We go in as one,' Thorg says. 'Hammers lead, we clear everything in our path.'

'That's just an excuse for you to hit things,' Brax grumbles.

'And what's wrong with that?!' Thorg shoots back.

'Nothing,' Grim says, spitting. 'It works. We're just saying you like it.'

Thorg grins. 'I really do.'

Brax rolls his eyes. 'Right. So hammers first, clearing rooms. We stay tight, we don't split up, and if anything big shows itself, we all three hit it until it stops moving.'

'That's the dwarven strategy for everything,' Grim notes.

'It's kept us alive this long,' Thorg counters.

They look at you. 'You with us, friend? Simple plan: go in together, hit hard, don't die.'

You nod. There's something reassuring about their simplicity. And their absolute confidence.

'Good lad!' Thorg claps you on the back again. 'Let's go kill some rats.'

title: Into the Den
text:
The four of you march into the den like you own the place. Which, to be fair, is the attitude that gets things killed.

'Hammers lead!' Thorg shouts, and all three dwarves raise their weapons.

Rats scatter. Literally everywhere. The first wave comes at you in a panicked rush.

Brax swings his hammer in a wide arc. 'TAKE THIS, YOU FURRY LITTLE—'

'Watch your swing!' Grim yells, spitting.

'I AM watching it!' Brax shoots back.

Thorg just grins and wades in. 'Less talking, more hitting!'

And they do. Hammers connect with rats. Rats fly. It's chaos, but it's *effective* chaos. These three have done this before.

You realize they're genuinely terrifying when they're serious. Funny, but terrifying.

gated_choices.label: Join in with shield and blade
Show them what your axe can do!

title: Shield and Fury
text:
You raise your shield and wade in alongside them. A rat lunges—you catch it on the shield and Thorg's hammer obliterates it.

'HAH! Shield work!' Thorg roars approvingly. 'Solid stance!'

'Don't get cocky!' Brax yells, swinging past you. 'These things bite!'

One does. Right at your ankle. You stomp it hard, blade following through. Dead rat.

'Nice footwork!' Grim shouts, spitting on a corpse.

For the next few minutes, it's a dance. You learn fast: hold the line with your shield, let the dwarves use that stability to swing wider. When they need a moment to reset, you step in with your blade. It's not perfect, but it works.

'You know,' Thorg says between strikes, 'I think you might actually be good at this!'

Then the first chamber opens up. Rats everywhere. But you're ready now.

title: Axe and Hammer
text:
You bring your axe up in a tight arc as a rat lunges. The blade catches it mid-leap. It's all momentum and power.

'THERE WE GO!' Thorg roars. 'AXE WORK! I LIKE IT!'

'Show off,' Brax grumbles, but he's grinning.

You swing again—another rat goes flying. The weight of the axe is familiar now, and the dwarves seem to respect the form.

'Swing's clean,' Grim notes between strikes. 'You've practiced.'

Thorg laughs. 'Of course they have. Look at that arc!'

For the next few minutes, you're in rhythm with them. Axe, hammer, hammer, axe. The dwarves adjust their positioning to complement your weapon. When you swing wide, they cover tight. When you go low, they take the high shots.

It's like they've fought alongside axe users their whole lives. Probably have.

'You know what?' Thorg says, breathing hard. 'You might actually be perfect for this.'

Then the first chamber opens up. Rats everywhere. But you're ready now.

title: The First Chamber
text:
Rats go down left and right. Not elegantly, but definitely finally.

Thorg kicks a rat corpse aside. 'How many's that?'

'Seventeen,' Brax calls out.

'I counted eighteen,' Grim says, spitting on a rat.

'You can't count past your beard,' Brax grumbles.

'Your beard is a lie!' Grim retorts.

They're bickering while looting bodies, which is somehow both ridiculous and oddly endearing. These three are basically a family that fights like they hate each other but would die for one another.

Thorg looks at you. 'You holding up okay, friend?'

There's genuine concern there, under the chaos.

choices.label: "Great!" You come to a rest with the others

title: Trophies and Banter
text:
Grim is handling trophies.

Grim crouches and starts collecting rat tails and feet with disturbing cheerfulness. 'These'll fetch decent coin.'

'Don't forget the teeth,' Thorg adds.

'I'm not an amateur,' Grim snaps, spitting.

Brax counts on his fingers. 'So that's... a lot of rats dead.'

'A LOT of rats dead,' Thorg agrees happily.

Grim stands up, grinning. 'And there's more coming. I can hear them deeper in.'

All three dwarves tense. The joking drops for a second.

'How much more?' you ask.

Thorg looks toward the deeper passages. 'Enough that we're probably finding the reason we got paid triple.'

The banter resumes. 'Well, let's go find it then!' Grim shouts.

title: Larger Chamber
text:
The passage opens into a massive chamber. Bones everywhere. Not rat bones.

Thorg stops dead. 'Well. That's new.'

'That's a deer skeleton,' Brax says quietly.

'Several deer skeletons,' Grim adds, also quiet.

The three dwarves exchange looks. All the joking stops. They move as one unit now, hammers ready, eyes sharp.

A shadow moves in the far corner of the chamber.

All three go very, very still.

'That,' Thorg whispers, 'is not just a rat.'

'And its more than Bigger,' Grim breathes.

'It's Huge!,' Brax finishes.

The shadow shifts again. Two red eyes catch the dim light filtering down.

Thorg draws a breath and grins. 'Here we go lads.'

They look to you. Silent question. You in?

You nod.

'Good,' Thorg says. 'Because I think we found our Rat King.'

title: The Rat King Emerges
text:
It emerges from the shadows.

For just a moment, even the dwarves lose their banter.

It's massive. Ten feet long. Fat. Scarred. Mean. The absolute apex of rat-kind, and it's looking at you like you're lunch.

'Well,' Grim says slowly. 'That's bigger than I expected.'

'A lot bigger,' Brax adds.

Thorg just grins. 'Perfect.'

The Rat King opens its maw and shrieks—a sound like tearing metal.

All three dwarves raise their hammers in perfect sync.

'FOR GLORY!' Thorg roars.

'FOR COIN!' Grim shouts.

'FOR NOT HAVING TO LISTEN TO THESE TWO ARGUE ANYMORE!' Brax yells, and then charges.

They move as one. Not in silence like professionals. They're YELLING. Hammers swinging. Coordinated chaos.

And somehow, watching them fight is like watching a perfectly choreographed dance—if the dance involved comically large hammers and screaming.

title: Hammers and Glory
text:
The Rat King meets them halfway. The impact shakes the chamber.

Thorg and Brax swing their hammers in a devastating one-two combo. Grim slides underneath, driving upward with a perfect strike.

'HAHAHAHA!' Thorg is laughing while fighting.

'Focus!' Brax yells, but he's grinning too.

The King fights back. It's fast, vicious, smart. But it's one against three who've fought like a unit for years.

Every swing is coordinated. When Thorg pins it left, Brax is ready on the right. When Grim goes low, they have his back.

You see it now—the reason they argue constantly. It's not spite. It's love. The kind of rapport that only comes from absolute trust.

The Rat King staggers. One final coordinated strike—all three hammers connect at once—and it's done.

The King falls.

The dwarves stand there, breathing hard, covered in filth and rat blood.

Then Thorg starts laughing. Really laughing.

'That,' he roars, 'was MAGNIFICENT!'

'That was expensive on my hammer!' Brax shoots back, but he's laughing too.

'Your hammer's fine,' Grim says, spitting. 'Unlike your face.'

Thorg claps you on the back so hard you stumble. 'You did good, friend. Real good. You're one of us now.'

There's no question in it. Just fact.

title: Victory Lap
text:
Thorg extracts the giant rat eye from the corpse. He holds it up like a trophy.

'Behold! The Prize of Pidling!'

'That's disgusting,' Brax says.

'That's beautiful,' Grim counters, spitting on the ground in what might be respect.

Thorg hands the eye to you. 'Yours friend. You earned it.'

You didn't, actually. It was all three of them. But they're giving it to you anyway.

'Come on lads,' Thorg says, already heading toward the exit. 'We've got coin to collect and ales to drink. In that order.'

'Ales first,' Brax argues.

'Coin first,' Grim insists.

'ALES FIRST!' all three roar at once, and you realize they'd argue about this even if they agreed.

But they're all moving toward the exit. Together.

title: Guild Reception
text:
You burst through the guild doors, the three dwarves loudly announcing your arrival.

'WE KILLED THE RAT KING!' Thorg bellows.

The receptionist looks up and immediately bursts out laughing. She knows these three.

'You're alive?'

'We're always alive,' Brax protests.

'Last time you came in here you were on fire,' she says.

'Coincidence,' Grim snaps, but he's grinning.

You place the giant rat eye on the counter. The whole hall goes quiet.

Then the receptionist whistles.

'Seems like your aFull adventurer now' she says to you. 'Im happy these three idiots kept you safe.' She slides the tokens and papers across, plus a hefty purse.

'We're not idiots,' Brax says.

'We're the best idiots,' Thorg agrees.

'We're idiot legends,' Grim finishes.

They clink their tankards together, celebrating like they just won a war.

And somehow, you feel like you did.

title: Words from the Lads
text:
Later, After some Merry Making that night, Thorg pulls out a crumpled piece of parchment. He shoves it into your hand.

'Before we disappear for a week,' he says.

You unfold it. The handwriting is rough but earnest, and all three have signed it.

'You came in as a stranger and left as family. That's not something we give out easy. You've got the instincts, the guts, and most importantly—you didn't complain once. That makes you either brave or stupid. Probably both.

If you're ever looking for work or just looking for good company, head to Trodden Hollow and ask for us. We'll be there. We'll buy you an ale. We'll probably argue about something stupid. And we'll do it all again.

You're one of us now. That's not changing.

—Thorg, Brax, Grim'

Thorg claps your shoulder. 'Right then. We're off to drink for a week straight. You earned your place here, friend. Enjoy it.'

They're already heading out, arguing about which tavern to hit first.

But not before Thorg turns back and winks.

title: A New Chapter
where_when: Guild hall, standing by the counter
text:
You slip the note into your pack, next to the giant rat eye. Your Guild Seal heavy in your hand. The adventurer's seal rests in its leather case.

You are no longer a newcomer. You are no longer untested.

You're also no longer alone.

Around you, the guild hums with life. Adventurers planning runs. Recruits dreaming of glory. The receptionist already calling out new contracts.

You've earned your place. And more than that—you've found your people.

Now the real adventure begins.

title: The End
text: Your adventure has come to a swift and brutal end. The world fades to black, and the finality of your choices settles in. Your tale is over before it truly began, a cautionary lesson on biting off more than you can chew. You really should make wiser choices so you dont have any regrets.
